TITLE: U.S. Pours Money Into Chips, but Even Soaring Spending Has Limits
SUMMARY: Amid a tech cold war with China, U.S. companies have pledged nearly $200 billion for chip manufacturing projects since early 2020. But the investments are not a silver bullet.

TITLE: U.K. Rail Strike May Scuttle Post-Holiday Plans to Return to Work
SUMMARY: Public sympathy for striking nurses and other health workers is particularly strong, posing a challenge for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, who has promised to confront trade unions.

TITLE: How Russia’s War on Ukraine Is Worsening Global Starvation
SUMMARY: Moscow blocks most shipments from Ukraine, one of the world’s largest wheat producers, and its attacks on the country’s energy grid also disrupt the flow of food.

TITLE: Japan’s Business Owners Can’t Find Successors. This Man Is Giving His Away.
SUMMARY: An owner’s struggle in Japan’s northern dairy region illuminates one of the potentially devastating economic impacts of an aging society.

TITLE: Why Japan’s Sudden Shift on Bond Purchases Dealt a Global Jolt
SUMMARY: The world has relied on ultralow interest rates in Japan. What will happen if they rise?

TITLE: Wave of Job-Switching Has Employers on a Training Treadmill
SUMMARY: The rise in turnover since the pandemic started has a cost in productivity: “It’s taking longer to get stuff out the door.”

TITLE: Fed Officials Fretted That Markets Would Misread Rate Slowdown
SUMMARY: Central bankers remained committed to wrestling inflation lower, and wanted to make sure investors understood that message, minutes from its December meeting showed.

TITLE: Labor Market Strength Persisted Heading Into the Holidays
SUMMARY: Government data from November showed job openings remained high, with rates of quitting and layoffs holding steady.

TITLE: Fed Official Compares Inflation to Uber Surge Pricing
SUMMARY: Neel Kashkari, the president of the Minneapolis Fed, kicked off 2023 monetary policy debates with a call for better understanding of what causes inflation.

TITLE: Auto Sales Likely Fell in 2022 Because of Supply Chain Chaos
SUMMARY: Automakers have been hampered by the supply of semiconductors and higher interest rates.

TITLE: U.S. Moves to Bar Noncompete Agreements in Labor Contracts
SUMMARY: A sweeping proposal by the Federal Trade Commission would block companies from limiting their employees’ ability to work for a rival.

TITLE: Bed Bath & Beyond Warns of Possible Bankruptcy
SUMMARY: The home goods retailer said weak sales and slower foot traffic had forced it to consider options for restructuring.

TITLE: Supply Problems Hurt Auto Sales in 2022. Now Demand Is Weakening.
SUMMARY: A global semiconductor shortage is easing, which could allow carmakers to lift production this year. But higher interest rates could keep sales low.

TITLE: Eurozone Inflation Eases on Lower Energy Prices
SUMMARY: The rate of price increases in countries using the euro slowed to 9.2 percent in December, down from 10.1 percent a month earlier.

TITLE: Even a Soft Landing for the Economy May Be Uneven
SUMMARY: Small businesses and lower-income families could feel pinched in the months ahead whether or not a recession is avoided this year.
